results.title:
Chronophotographic prints
Arab Horse Gallop
results.credit_line: Courtesy Art Collection 4 / Granger Historical Picture Archive / Alamy
results.brief_description: French scientist Étienne-Jules Marey’s chronophotographic technique captured kinetic motion through multiple exposures in one photo. He used a photographic rifle with a revolving cylinder that shot 12 frames a second.
results.credit_line_for_label: Courtesy Art Collection 4 / Granger Historical Picture Archive / Alamy

results.title:
Sequential photographs
Motion Studies: Straight High Jump
results.credit_line: Courtesy Heritage Image Partnership Ltd / World History Archive / Welcome Collection / Alamy
results.brief_description: British American photographer Eadweard Muybridge laid the foundation of the moving image. Using multiple cameras triggered by trip wires, he captured a galloping horse in sequential images, reproduced them in a zoetrope and created the world’s first moving photographs.
results.credit_line_for_label: Courtesy Heritage Image Partnership Ltd / World History Archive / Welcome Collection / Alamy

details.label: Curatorial sections
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Pictures → 03. Time and Movement

results.title:
Gelatin silver print
Golfer
results.brief_description: American professor Harold ‘Doc’ Edgerton’s pioneering development of the electric stroboscopic flash suspended movement, stopping skipping ropes mid-swing – and even speeding bullets.
